fields.title: Yangon, Myanmar
A shield displaying the White Hand of Isengard

fields.body:
[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

My trip started on Platform 7 of bustling Yangon Central Station, Myanmar\u2019s largest train station, built by the British in 1877. Heading counterclockwise, the train crawled through sprawling rail depots and repair yards. Soon the larger, national trains branched off and headed north, and the six tracks thinned to two, servicing the Circle Line alone.

", "id": "b0b3a5c6-82c9-4cad-80e0-04df8e396f72"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As the train moved up Yangon\u2019s east side, mildew-stained buildings started to give way to farmland. The carriages gradually emptied out as the train looped around the city\u2019s northern reaches, past open fields, a golf course, a military base and palm huts where some of Yangon\u2019s poorest live.

", "id": "1c3311f0-fd08-46ea-adb5-b43fe438ef67"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Railway employees are supposed to wear crisp, white Myanmar Railways shirts with epaulets. But at some of the route\u2019s 38 stations, like Danyingon in the north, they frequently strip down to their undershirts to keep cool in the sweltering ticket booths and control rooms, which often do not have a working fan.

", "id": "677d6809-dda9-4267-a52c-37557e46d3f2"}]

fields.introduction: We provide unforgettable experiences through love and care.

fields.body:
[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "


Tour snapshot

  • Greet the day the local way! Grab a local-style breakfast, then go for a market wander, see a few temples, and enjoy a tasty lunch on this all-in-one food-meets-culture Mandalay.\u00a0

Highlights

  • Experience local life in Mandalay in the tastiest way: through its food!
  • Wander the city\u2019s vibrant morning markets, including the Zaycho and Mingalar markets.
  • Enjoy an authentic Burmese breakfast and lunch with local dishes like kyae oh\u00a0\u00a0and moh hin ga.
  • Explore the palace, the last Burmese king lived.

    Inclusions: Local English-speaking guide, breakfast and lunch, coffee break, entrance fees, transportation.\u00a0

    Exclusions: Additional food and drink, souvenirs and items of a personal nature, tips/gratuities for drivers and guide.\u00a0

", "id": "f6fc5c95-4d8e-4643-a8f8-26d086a465c4"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Tour snapshot

    Tap into local culture in Los Angeles! Join us for\u00a0an orientation tour\u00a0of Hollywood.\u00a0Hang out with\u00a0an in-the-know local\u00a0who can\u00a0introduce you to the city\u00a0and tell you what to do, where to go, and how to make the most of your time\u00a0in\u00a0LA.\u00a0\u00a0

  • Highlights

    • Chat with a Los Angeles-based local expert who can help you plan your Best. Days. Ever. while you\u2019re in town
    • Learn all the secret local tips you won\u2019t find in most guidebooks
    • Meet up with fellow like-minded travellers
    • Take a mini tour of Hollywood
    • Kick back with new friends at a funky spot in a great neighbourhood

    • Inclusions: Local English-speaking expert to answer all your questions.

    Exclusions: Transportation to and from the meet-up point, food and drinks.

", "id": "16f95691-45e2-4d16-b461-afcd4e78b3c4"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Get picked up at your hotel for a private 4 hour sightseeing tour of the Ancient Bagan, Irraweddy river, and perhaps a couple of other beautiful places along the way.

", "id": "63313aaa-b6a7-430d-bb25-92cbfcaaef7e"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Yes, it is just as romantic as it sounds!

Escape the crowds of Yangon and enjoy one of Ngwesaung's spectacular sunsets with amazing views of the bay of Bangal from the water. Spend 2 hours on your own private yacht- a romantic sail for 2 or up to a group of 6.

BYOB.

", "id": "19962160-27cb-45c4-aab5-0a42c47b2cdf"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Once the Kingdom, Mandalay is now known as the largest street art gallery in the Myanmar! Made famous by the yearly art fair, the Mandalay area has exploded into one of the hippest neighborhoods in the country. From wheat pastes to murals, stencils to stickers, every inch of the neighborhood is covered in art. This walking tour of the neighborhood will include information about the street art coupled with the history of the neighborhood, the ins-and-outs of the current changes, and the way that Mandalay fits into the overall picture of Myanmar. I can give tours in both English and French, and I can arrange for bike rentals for an additional fee. Come and check out Mandalay's street art hub!

", "id": "f2bf264e-cd7f-466b-960f-468cafe59887"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

On this Yangon walking tour, your guide will give you an orientation of the neighbourhood that includes places most visitors never see, and stop by several shops where you can purchase local foods to try.

", "id": "11dcaeba-8aca-41e3-813e-82deb28e4d6d"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Ever plan a whole elaborate Inlay shebang just to come back with blurry photos taken at sweaty clubs? Document your special outing or have a fun photo shoot in style with Kyaw Kyaw and his crew. He'll take you on a photo shoot tour of some of the most scenic locations in Inle. A long-time resident of Taungyi, he can even give you pointers and tips for the rest of your trip for both on Inle and Taungyi.

Package also includes photo retouching, an online gallery & instant digital download of the high resolution images with a usage & copyright release.

", "id": "74cae61e-f37b-4f43-b0d7-35c42cb30baf"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Get ready to witness the best-of-the-best as your excursion begins with a journey past Irraweddy.

", "id": "51e06979-956e-46ba-966b-6ed625c4ae78"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Uncover the astounding mix of nationalities that make up the City of Mawlamyine on this Mawlamyine food tour that reveals hole-in-the-wall eateries, markets, snack shops.

", "id": "dafa5db7-0707-48e4-8c52-e92edb57aaf4"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"image": 37, "caption": "", "style": "contain"}, "id": "9014ee3f-0845-44a7-baa3-08d4e0c0c023"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"image": 38, "caption": "", "style": "contain"}, "id": "202ddfa0-d98e-48a5-b7e7-bcabe1650cea"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Highlights

    • Taste sweet and savory foods from Chinatown.
    • Experience the culture and learn the history of these diverse neighborhoods
    • Admire ornate historic architecture and get a glimpse of the bay of Bangal.

    • Inclusions: Select sweet and savory tastings (vegetarian options available with\u00a0advance notice upon booking); Some drinks (non-alcoholic) and water;\u00a0 English speaking local guide.

    Notes: Please indicate vegetarian preferences or any dietary restrictions upon booking. We will do our best to accommodate them although we cannot guarantee an alternative option at each stop.

    Exclusions: Additional food and drink items, return transportation to start point, tips / gratuities for your guide

", "id": "fcc6bfe7-715b-4d81-a651-e00e1b2c5455"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bgrLAaD5niI", "id": "317ea0a4-f702-412a-8ef8-ba7403473543"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Tour Snapshot

A fun packed tour for some of the most amazing sites in Yangon. Will learn the local way of life, eat the local food and shopping at Bogyoke market.

Highlights

  • Amazing view of Sule pagoda.
  • Photo ops with Yangon City Hall and colonial buildings.
  • Cross river with Yangon Jetty see some of Myanmar people's way of life
  • Sacred site of Chaukhtgyi pagoda.
  • Shopping at Bogyoke market, one of the tourist attractions in the city of Yangon.
  • Sunset view at the great Shwedagon pagoda.

What's included

Local english-speaking guide, transportation and entrance fees.

What's Not included

Food and drink, souvenirs and items of a personal nature, tips/gratuities for drivers and guide.\u00a0

", "id": "d1e34e80-9c7f-44bf-ba14-db931bab2573"}]

fields.introduction: Our select hosts can provide neighborhood-specific tips to guests so they can experience the same local restaurants and shops they themselves love.

fields.body:
[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Aragorn is the son of Arathorn. He is one of the main protagonists of The Lord of the Rings. Aragorn was a Ranger of the North, first introduced with the name Strider at Bree, as the Hobbits continued to call him throughout The Lord of the Rings. He was eventually discovered to be the heir of Isildur and rightful claimant to the thrones of Arnor and Gondor. He was also a confidant of Gandalf and an integral part of the quest to destroy the One Ring and defeat the Dark Lord Sauron.

", "id": "d8270116-8c24-44cf-b9e4-9e6433a47410"}, {"type": "blockquote", "value": {"text": "Let's hunt some Orc.", "attribute_name": "Aragorn", "attribute_group": ""}, "id": "f0fdda7b-7ba8-4fe6-8da8-56a8019fc493"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Aragorn led the Fellowship of the Ring following the loss of Gandalf in the Mines of Moria while fighting the Balrog. When the Fellowship was broken, he tracked the hobbits Meriadoc Brandybuck and Peregrin Took with the help of Legolas the elf and Gimli the dwarf to Fangorn Forest. Then he fought in the battle at Helm's Deep and the Battle of the Pelennor Fields. After defeating Sauron's forces in Gondor, he led an army of Gondor and Rohan against the Black Gate of Mordor to distract Sauron's attention so that Frodo Baggins and Samwise Gamgee could have a chance to destroy the One Ring.


At the end of The Lord of the Rings, Aragorn was crowned King Elessar Telcontar (\"Elfstone Strider\") of Gondor. He married Elrond's daughter, Arwen, and assumed the Sceptre of Ann\u00faminas as King of Arnor, uniting the two kingdoms for the first time since the reign of Isildur.

", "id": "2ea91095-11b9-4468-bfb5-c1d734f530d6"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "History", "size": "h2"}, "id": "ac24e24c-afea-46a7-9f59-6deb68dfddac"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The son of Arathorn II and his wife Gilraen, Aragorn was born on 1 March, T.A. 2931.[1] Through his ancestor Elendil (whom he closely resembled)[2] Aragorn was a descendant of the first king of N\u00famenor, Elros Tar-Minyatur; the twin brother of Elrond

", "id": "c10fcc06-6aac-47f2-8952-02d2bd0e8aac"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When Aragorn was two years old, his father was killed while pursuing orcs. Aragorn was afterwards fostered in Rivendell by Elrond. At the bidding of Elrond, his lineage was kept secret, as Elrond feared he would be killed like his father and grandfather if his true identity as Isildur's heir became known. Aragorn was renamed Estel (\"hope\" in Sindarin) to hide his existence from Sauron and his servants. He was not told about his heritage until he came of age in 2951.[1]

", "id": "434c2c40-380c-44db-bc63-96ba1fca88c0"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/2H4Q_aA4QiQ", "id": "84bc5341-a119-4f59-b03a-9d39bdaba9ce"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Elrond revealed to Aragorn his true name and ancestry, and delivered to him the shards of Elendil's sword Narsil, and also the Ring of Barahir. He withheld the Sceptre of Ann\u00faminas from him until he earned the right to possess it. Aragorn met and fell in love with Arwen, Elrond's daughter (whom he mistook for Tin\u00faviel), when she returned from L\u00f3rien, her mother's homeland.[1]

", "id": "630e6edf-9017-41ef-a52f-580291139195"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Aragorn thereafter assumed his role as the sixteenth Chieftain of the D\u00fanedain, the Rangers of the North, and went into the wild, living with the remnants of his hosts, whose kingdom had been destroyed through civil and regional wars centuries before.

", "id": "85a15610-1d4b-4c90-a162-f5f37d713925"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Aragorn met Gandalf the Grey in 2956, and they became close friends.[1] The Rangers help to guard the Shire, inhabited by the diminutive, agrarian Hobbits. In the areas around the Shire and Bree he became known as \"Strider\".[3]

", "id": "18047097-6b4b-4623-b091-e3cd12dbd0a4"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

From 2957 to 2980, Aragorn undertook great journeys, serving in the armies of King Thengel of Rohan (King Th\u00e9oden's father) and of Steward Ecthelion II of Gondor (father of Denethor). His tasks helped to raise morale in the West and to counter the growing threat of Sauron and his allies, and he acquired experience that he would later put to use in the War of the Ring. Aragorn served his lords during that time under the name Thorongil (Eagle of the Star). With a small squadron of ships from Gondor, he led an assault on Umbar in 2980, burning many of the Corsairs' ships and personally slaying their lord during the Battle of the Havens. After the victory at Umbar, \"Thorongil\" left the field, to the dismay of his men, and went East.[1]

", "id": "e3e04497-9c43-4505-8b8d-bf6fd7c36d11"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Aragorn also travelled through the Dwarves' mines of Moria and to Rh\u00fbn and Harad, where (in his own words) \"the stars are strange\".

", "id": "55ff0632-0c9e-487a-87a2-66a1358c68d2"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In 2980, he visited L\u00f3rien, and there again met Arwen. He gave her an heirloom of his House, the Ring of Barahir,[4] and, on the hill of Cerin Amroth, Arwen pledged her hand to him in marriage, renouncing her Elvish lineage and accepting mortality, the \"Gift of Men\". Elrond withheld from Aragorn permission to marry his daughter until such time as his foster son should be king of Gondor and Arnor reunited. To marry a mortal, Arwen would be required to choose mortality and thus eventually separate the immortal Elrond from his daughter; and Elrond feared that in the end Arwen might find the prospect of death too difficult to bear.[1]

", "id": "a4b8a961-dca4-4435-9338-5a555c29b3f0"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Gandalf grew suspicious of the ring belonging to the hobbit Bilbo Baggins, which was later discovered to be Sauron's One Ring.[5] Gandalf asked Aragorn to track Gollum, who had previously possessed the Ring. This hunt led Aragorn across Rhovanion, and he finally captured Gollum in the Dead Marshes northwest of Mordor and brought him captive to King Thranduil\u2019s halls in Mirkwood, where Gandalf questioned him.

", "id": "dda349ce-c25b-493e-84b9-4717302dbffd"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I am working as an English speaking guide in the region as well as different regions in Myanmar for nearly 8 years. I loveM and proud of its amazing nature, a deep orient culture blended with local traditional customs and its unforgettable history. Showing them to you, my travelers, is my passion. Your satisfaction about the trip is my happiness. You will come back to visit a place when you like a place so much. Thus making you falling in love with my country is my mission. I will customize your trip upon your special requests to help you with just a limited time, but so much to enjoy.

", "id": "7384c27b-5be7-4cd0-a59a-14bf506343cc"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Boromir\u00a0is a character in\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\u00a0legendarium. He appears in the first two volumes of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings\u00a0(The Fellowship of the Ring\u00a0and\u00a0The Two Towers), and is mentioned in the last volume,\u00a0The Return of the King. He is the heir of\u00a0Denethor II\u00a0(the 26th\u00a0Ruling Stewardof\u00a0Gondor) and the elder brother of\u00a0Faramir. In the course of the story Boromir joins the\u00a0Fellowship of the Ring.

", "id": "60653e35-9927-4b28-8c53-6b577248ab1e"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Boromir is portrayed as a noble character who believes passionately in the greatness of his kingdom, who would have defended its hosts to the last. Boromir's great stamina and physical strength, together with a forceful and commanding personality, made him a widely admired commander in Gondor's army: he was made Captain of the White Tower, and quickly became Captain-General, also bearing the title High Warden of the White Tower. He was also heir apparent to the Stewardship. Boromir led many successful forays against\u00a0Sauron's forces, prior to his journey north to\u00a0Rivendell, which brought him great esteem in the eyes of his father, Denethor.

", "id": "d2630659-1b4c-46a6-b1f4-f9cfcaf06a17"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "Literature", "size": "h2"}, "id": "7a518e93-b038-4b85-ab3c-a1cfd9697a60"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Boromir, as a character, is portrayed as having been born in the year 2978 of the\u00a0Third Age\u00a0to\u00a0Denethor II\u00a0and\u00a0Finduilas, daughter of Adrahil of\u00a0Dol Amroth. His younger brother,\u00a0Faramir, was born in the year\u00a0T.A.\u00a02983. The following year, Denethor became Steward of Gondor, succeeding his father,\u00a0Ecthelion II. Boromir simultaneously became heir apparent, inheriting the\u00a0Horn of Gondor.

", "id": "239522e7-bcde-4c88-b116-71f628daa823"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Boromir was named after the son of\u00a0Denethor I, who was Steward around 500 years before the War of the Ring. The\u00a0first Boromir\u00a0was known as a great captain who cleared\u00a0Ithilien\u00a0of orcs of\u00a0Mordor\u00a0and was feared even by the\u00a0Witch-king\u00a0himself. Thus there were high expectations for Boromir the son of Denethor II.

", "id": "06b6100c-0691-404c-aeca-26169f0d77d2"}, {"type": "blockquote", "value": {"text": "It is a strange fate that we should suffer so much fear and doubt over so small a thing. Such a little thing.", "attribute_name": "Boromir", "attribute_group": ""}, "id": "74bb06f0-86da-4b02-a339-3e98bcf74547"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When Boromir's mother Finduilas died (T.A.\u00a02988), he was aged only 10. Denethor became sombre, cold and detached from his family. As their father withdrew, the relationship between Faramir and Boromir grew closer and greater in love. Denethor always favoured Boromir over Faramir\u2014Denethor loved Boromir \"too much, perhaps; the more so because they were unlike\"[1]\u2014but this caused no rivalry between the two brothers. Boromir always protected and helped Faramir. Boromir was judged to be the more daring one, as well as the more fearless.

", "id": "d198fa37-7868-4e97-9838-ab6aa914877b"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In response to prophetic dreams that came to Faramir and later to himself, Boromir claimed the quest of riding to\u00a0Rivendell\u00a0from\u00a0Minas Tirith\u00a0in\u00a0T.A.\u00a03018. His journey lasted a hundred and eleven days, and he travelled through \"roads forgotten\" to reach Rivendell, though, as he said, \"few knew where it lay\".[2]\u00a0Boromir lost his horse halfway along, while crossing the\u00a0Greyfloodat the ruined city of\u00a0Tharbad\u00a0where the bridge was broken. He had to travel the remaining way on foot[3]\u00a0and barely arrived in time for the Council of Elrond. (Tolkien wrote of Boromir's journey that \"the courage and hardihood required is not fully recognized in the narrative\".)[4]

", "id": "778528d9-fb50-4f3a-bb01-3045296dc824"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Saruman the White\u00a0is a fictional character and a major antagonist in\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's fantasy novel\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. He is leader of the\u00a0Istari, wizards sent to\u00a0Middle-earth\u00a0in human form by the godlike\u00a0Valar\u00a0to challenge\u00a0Sauron, the main antagonist of the novel, but eventually he desires Sauron's power for himself and tries to take over Middle-earth by force. His schemes feature prominently in the second volume,\u00a0The Two Towers, and at the end of the third volume,\u00a0The Return of the King. His earlier history is given briefly in the posthumously published\u00a0The Silmarillion\u00a0and\u00a0Unfinished Tales.

", "id": "b0637a06-faf2-4ff7-a530-571f3de964a5"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Saruman is one of several characters in the book illustrating the corruption of power; his desire for knowledge and order leads to his fall, and he rejects the chance of redemption when it is offered. The name\u00a0Saruman\u00a0[\u02c8saruman]\u00a0means \"man of experience\" in the\u00a0Mercian dialect\u00a0of\u00a0Anglo-Saxon;[1]\u00a0he serves as an example of technology and modernity being overthrown by forces more in tune with nature. Saruman is represented by a white hand.

", "id": "9dbe31f7-647d-4a38-a72b-c786518b6f22"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "Characterisation", "size": "h2"}, "id": "c57d50f2-b015-4e5c-8eb8-c652be6d7111"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Tolkien described Saruman at the time of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings\u00a0as having a long face and a high forehead, \"...he had deep darkling eyes ... His hair and beard were white, but strands of black still showed around his lips and ears.\"[24]\u00a0His hair is elsewhere described as having been black when he first arrived in Middle-earth. He is referred to as 'Saruman the White' and is said to have originally worn white robes, but on his first entry in\u00a0The Fellowship of the Ring\u00a0they instead appear to be \"woven from all colours [, they] shimmered and changed hue so that the eye was bewildered\" and he names himself 'Saruman of Many Colours'.[25]

", "id": "850d64fc-d5fc-450b-be5e-17fadad4dd42"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/TQq4LjSF2rc", "id": "df66cd35-45d7-47aa-94fe-c6e3f921230f"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The power of Saruman's voice is noted throughout the book. Jonathan Evans calls the characterization of Saruman in the chapter\u00a0The Voice of Saruman\u00a0a \"tour de force\".[20]\u00a0Roger Sale\u00a0says of the same chapter that \"Tolkien valiantly tried to do something worth doing which he simply cannot bring off.\"[26]\u00a0Tom Shippey\u00a0writes that \"Saruman talks like a politician ... No other character in Middle-earth has Saruman's trick of balancing phrases against each other so that incompatibles are resolved, and none comes out with words as empty as 'deploring', 'ultimate', worst of all, 'real'. What is 'real change'?\"[27]Shippey contrasts this modern speech pattern with the archaic stoicism and directness that Tolkien employs for other characters such as the\u00a0Dwarven\u00a0King\u00a0D\u00e1in, which Shippey believes represent Tolkien's view of heroism in the mould of\u00a0Beowulf.[27]

", "id": "94f71795-f6f1-4685-b5e6-903dfc0d4d21"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After the defeat of his armies, having been caught in the betrayal of Sauron, Saruman is offered refuge by Gandalf, in return for his aid, but having chosen his path, is unable to turn from it.[28]\u00a0Evans has compared the character of Saruman to that of\u00a0Satan\u00a0in\u00a0John Milton's\u00a0Paradise Lost\u00a0in his use of rhetoric and in this final refusal of redemption, \"conquered by pride and hatred\".[20]

", "id": "772ddee7-5c16-4070-9cce-e7e6e4768b85"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

My name is Su. Extrovert introvertis which means I am very extrovert but whenever i have free time, I just want to spend time alone.


I love traveling, speaking different languages and meeting new people. I am working as freelancer which has given me flexible schedule and the opportunity to interact with lots of foreigners.


I love music. Playing guitar on singing is my favorite thing to entertain when I am free.


I love doing work out and i pay lots attention to healthy eating.


Last year, I worked as a tour guide in a travel agency with an original idea about tourism. That job helped me understand the insights of clients (and expats living in Yangon also) and improved my communication ability.


I am signing up for this website because I do really enjoy guiding people in a friendly way. If you take me as your tourguide, you need to know in advance that I am not a 'traditional' guide who comes with tons of info, I will probably not know everything but will always try my best to satisfy your curiosity/questions about Myanmar.

", "id": "56ef5013-a737-4910-a6ed-a144026d7bc1"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Th\u00e9oden\u00a0is a fictional character in\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\u00a0fantasy\u00a0novel,\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. The King of\u00a0Rohan, he appears as a major supporting character in\u00a0The Two Towers\u00a0and\u00a0The Return of the King.

", "id": "d3eaf6f8-0666-452d-bcfd-319f1e6be698"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "Appearances", "size": "h2"}, "id": "3fb13bb2-4447-4e12-a631-d4176bda10c5"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Th\u00e9oden is introduced in\u00a0The Two Towers, the second volume of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, as the King of\u00a0Rohan. By the time of the\u00a0War of the Ring, Th\u00e9oden had grown weak with age, and was largely controlled by his chief advisor\u00a0Gr\u00edma\u00a0(or\u00a0Wormtongue\u00a0as most others in the\u00a0Riddermark\u00a0called him), who was secretly in the employ of the corrupt wizard\u00a0Saruman. In\u00a0Unfinished Tales, it is implied that the failure of the king's health was \"...induced or increased by subtle poisons, administered by Gr\u00edma\".[1]\u00a0As Th\u00e9oden sat powerless, Rohan was troubled by\u00a0Orcs\u00a0and\u00a0Dunlendings, who operated under the\u00a0will\u00a0of Saruman, ruling from\u00a0Isengard.

", "id": "670f18f9-0e19-4ab3-b6f4-aa16bc937f91"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When his son\u00a0Th\u00e9odred\u00a0was mortally wounded at a\u00a0battle at the Fords of Isen, Th\u00e9oden's nephew\u00a0\u00c9omer\u00a0became his heir. However, \u00c9omer was out of favour with Wormtongue, who eventually had him arrested.

", "id": "481df16f-5d70-4cfa-9662-239b00c8385a"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When\u00a0Gandalf the White\u00a0and\u00a0Aragorn, along with Legolas and Gimli, appeared before him in\u00a0The Two Towers, Th\u00e9oden initially rebuffed the\u00a0wizard's advice to oppose Saruman. When Gandalf revealed Wormtongue for what he was, however, Th\u00e9oden returned to his senses. He restored his nephew, took up his sword\u00a0Herugrim, and in spite of his age, led the Riders of Rohan into the\u00a0Battle of the Hornburg. After this he became known as Th\u00e9oden Ednew, the Renewed.

", "id": "dcb3599d-dfb9-4e71-ba91-5abdecc6a027"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In\u00a0The Return of the King, Th\u00e9oden led the Rohirrim to the aid of\u00a0Gondor\u00a0at the\u00a0Battle of the Pelennor Fields. In that battle he routed the\u00a0Harad\u00a0cavalry, personally killing their chieftain and banner-bearer in the process. He challenged the\u00a0Witch-king of Angmar, the leader of the\u00a0Nazg\u00fbl, and was mortally wounded when his horse\u00a0Snowmane\u00a0fell upon him. He was avenged by his niece\u00a0\u00c9owyn\u00a0and the\u00a0hobbit\u00a0Meriadoc \"Merry\" Brandybuck, who had ridden to war in secret; together, they destroyed the Witch-king. Before mustering the Rohirrim to ride to Gondor's aid, Th\u00e9oden enlisted Merry into his army, but did not let the hobbit ride into\u00a0battle at Pelennor. In his last moments, he bid farewell to Merry and appointed \u00c9omer the next king.

", "id": "7dc99bec-505b-4614-bc28-09977e298dd1"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Th\u00e9oden's body lay in\u00a0Minas Tirith\u00a0until it was buried in Rohan after the defeat of\u00a0Sauron. He was the last of the Second Line of the kings, judging from direct descent from\u00a0Eorl the Young.

", "id": "0ef2e64b-3ce2-48c8-bdff-6d34b37a18e3"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Treebeard\u00a0(Sindarin:\u00a0Fangorn) is a fictional character from\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\u00a0Middle-earth\u00a0fantasy writings. The eldest of the species of\u00a0Ents, he is said to live in the ancient\u00a0Forest of Fangorn\u00a0and stands fourteen feet (4 m) in height. He is treelike in appearance, with leafy hair and a rigid structure.[1]\u00a0His home of Fangorn Forest lies next to\u00a0Isengard, where\u00a0Saruman the White\u00a0resides. Treebeard's motto is \"Do not be hasty.\"[1]

", "id": "591f15c2-b8c7-4ab6-977b-86b57c39a1fd"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In\u00a0The Two Towers\u00a0he meets with\u00a0Meriadoc Brandybuck\u00a0and\u00a0Peregrin Took, two\u00a0Hobbits\u00a0of\u00a0the Shire\u00a0known also as Merry and Pippin.[1]\u00a0Treebeard is known to have a strong hatred of\u00a0Orcs, and, after Saruman's betrayal of the Ents, of Saruman as well.[1][2]\u00a0During his initial encounter with the two hobbits, he is so agitated that he misidentifies them as orc spies. He then carries them to the white wizard.

", "id": "230f4f23-f698-4dae-85ae-444089b049f4"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Spirits were sent by\u00a0Eru Il\u00favatar\u00a0to inhabit the\u00a0trees, which the\u00a0Vala\u00a0Yavanna\u00a0had created along with other plants or\u00a0olvar. The Vala longed for their protection since\u00a0Morgoth\u00a0or\u00a0Melkor\u00a0was destroying the trees and olvar, which could not defend themselves from him. The Ents were created by Il\u00favatar at the behest of Yavanna as the\u00a0Shepherds of the Forest\u00a0or\u00a0Tree-herders.\u00a0Entwives\u00a0were also created for the Ents, but, in the\u00a0Second Age, were driven out by\u00a0Sauron.[1][2][3]

", "id": "0fa4ab70-f6ab-4ead-bac6-1fc94f5daed0"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Treebeard is the oldest of three remaining original Ents.[1][4]\u00a0He is said to have once roamed all of the forests in Middle-earth, which included the\u00a0Misty Mountains,\u00a0Mirkwood,\u00a0Mordor, and the Blue Mountains. After the loss of the Entwives by the end of the\u00a0Third Age, he and the remaining Ents dwelt in the Forest of Fangorn. This led the remaining Ents into isolation and all information from the outside world was cut off.[1]\u00a0The arrival of Merry and Pippin shifted Treebeard's attention to take action against Saruman for hacking down his trees. He led the Ents to war against Saruman and his Orcs. Treebeard later realised that while Saruman had learned much from him, the Wizard had shared no useful information of his own.[1]

", "id": "e1333d7c-cb20-4bfe-8cb8-8ed17527014c"}, {"type": "blockquote", "value": {"text": "A large Man-like figure, at least fourteen foot high, very sturdy, with a tall head, and hardly any neck. Whether it was clad in stuff like green and grey bark, or whether that was its hide, was difficult to say. Arms, at a short distance from the trunk, were not wrinkled, but covered with a brown smooth skin. The large feet had seven toes each. Grey beard, deep brown eyes, shot with a green light.", "attribute_name": "JRR Tolkien", "attribute_group": ""}, "id": "e931da37-87ca-4565-8f1a-c44c772a2ae8"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Treebeard had been friends with Saruman. It is described in\u00a0The Two Towers\u00a0that Saruman visited Treebeard in Fangorn Forest and had talked with him on various subjects of concern. Saruman gathered information from Treebeard about the Forest of Fangorn; its intertwining paths were of particular concern to him.[1]

", "id": "020a51b1-6306-4fdd-8317-2b7dcb49291e"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After Merry and Pippin's meeting with Treebeard, Treebeard called an\u00a0Entmoot, which lasted three days, to decide to call an attack on Isengard and Saruman.[1][2][4]\u00a0Since\u00a0Leaflock\u00a0and\u00a0Skinbark\u00a0were the oldest of the Ents along with Treebeard, they refused to fight, however, Treebeard thought he was going to his doom during \"the last march of the Ents.\"[1][4]\u00a0Treebeard hoped that some of the younger Ents would come instead of just the two, and, during the night he spread the word. They later launched an assault on Isengard.[1][2][4]

", "id": "83558382-4e7b-49cf-a8fb-a5b1dd757742"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/BbV2Hr0qRdo", "id": "f5bd4c5c-589b-4e3a-8dee-f648ec7c41d7"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After Treebeard ordered the Ents to march to Isengard, the Ents felled Saruman's walls and destroyed every object in and around Isengard; the\u00a0Tower of Orthanc\u00a0could not be breached, but Saruman was trapped within. Treebeard stopped the attack on the tower when he realised their efforts were in vain; the tower was too strong. The Ents were ordered to unleash the waters of the\u00a0River Isen, which flooded Isengard.[2]\u00a0When Merry and Pippin departed Treebeard he requested them to watch for the Entwives.[1]\u00a0At one point in the book, Tolkien gives hints on the whereabouts of the Entwives. It is speculated that they were spotted by Samwise Gamgee's cousin Hal in the North Farthing.\u00a0

", "id": "5753a352-218f-4f62-85ef-ae673dafcb41"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I have travelled a lot for business and leisure and I can appreciate genuine hospitality. I love people who have the natural curiosity to explore other countries and I would be pleased to offer them an opportunity to relax and enjoy themselves.

", "id": "54422398-65f1-4cd4-82cc-5454ad2a9605"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Shelob\u00a0is a fictional\u00a0giant spider\u00a0from\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\u00a0Middle-earth\u00a0legendarium. She appears at the end of the fourth book, second volume (The Two Towers), of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. Her lair lies in\u00a0Cirith Ungol\u00a0(\"the pass of the spider\") leading into\u00a0Mordor.\u00a0Gollum\u00a0deliberately leads\u00a0Frodo Baggins\u00a0there in hopes of recovering the\u00a0One Ring\u00a0when Shelob attacks Frodo. The plan is foiled when\u00a0Samwise Gamgee\u00a0greatly injures Shelob with Frodo's Elvish dagger,\u00a0Sting, and the\u00a0Phial of Galadriel.

", "id": "140c13a5-9a92-43c9-9e08-17a2cf6b6f0b"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "Literature", "size": "h2"}, "id": "b638c423-ceab-4515-a3e3-3a8803f3d6b1"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Shelob was an \"evil thing in spider form...[the] last child of\u00a0Ungoliant\u00a0to trouble the unhappy world\",[1]\u00a0living high in the\u00a0Ephel D\u00faath\u00a0mountains on the borders of\u00a0Mordor. There are numerous references to her predating the events of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings\u00a0by many ages. Although she resided in Mordor and was unrepentantly evil, she was independent of\u00a0Sauron\u00a0and his influence.[2]

", "id": "426feda1-6041-4668-beaa-b5cd1555efb9"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This creature makes her first appearance in the chapter \"The Stairs of Cirith Ungol\", though she is formally introduced in the next chapter \"Shelob's Lair\" where the author says \"But still she was there, who was there before Sauron, and before the first stone of\u00a0Barad-d\u00fbr; and she served none but herself, drinking the blood of\u00a0Elves\u00a0and\u00a0Men, bloated and grown fat with endless brooding on her feasts, weaving webs of shadow; for all living things were her food, and her vomit darkness\". Her descendants include the\u00a0Giant Spiders\u00a0defeated by\u00a0Bilbo Baggins\u00a0in\u00a0The Hobbit.

", "id": "1c46bb51-61c8-49ea-89fc-9531aaf0a669"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Shelob's lair was\u00a0Torech Ungol, below Cirith Ungol (\"Pass of the Spider\"), along the path that\u00a0Sam Gamgee\u00a0and\u00a0Frodo Baggins\u00a0took into Mordor, where Shelob had encountered Gollum during his previous trip to Mordor, and he apparently worshipped her. The\u00a0Orcs\u00a0of the Tower of Cirith Ungol called her \"Shelob the Great\" and \"Her Ladyship\", and referred to Gollum as \"Her Sneak\". Sauron himself was aware of her existence, but left her alone, as a useful guard on the pass, and occasionally fed prisoners to her. In the story, Gollum led the\u00a0Hobbits\u00a0into her lair to himself recover the\u00a0One Ring\u00a0after she consumed them. She cornered them; but Frodo used the Phial of Galadriel's light to drive her off, and used Sting to cut the webs blocking the tunnel. Gollum waylaid the pair and tried to strangle Sam, while Shelob paralysed Frodo; whereafter Sam fought off Gollum and then wielded Sting against Shelob. Seeking to crush Sam, she instead impaled herself upon\u00a0Sting; and was nearly blinded by the Phial of Galadriel; whereupon she fled. Thinking Frodo dead, Sam took the Ring from his friend and left his body behind, but discovered by listening to a pair of Orcs that Frodo was alive but senseless, under a minor influence of\u00a0venom.

", "id": "35b5e220-92e0-4553-9235-46276218bcbe"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/pA0ffVBw584", "id": "49346929-f1d9-45fa-b8ce-dae51a06aac0"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "Name", "size": "h2"}, "id": "ab188991-0706-4b07-a518-8624a7918dd1"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As Tolkien admitted in a letter to his son, Shelob \"is of course only 'she + lob',\" -\u00a0lob\u00a0being an archaic English word for spider, influenced by\u00a0Old English\u00a0loppe\u00a0or \"spider\". The word is not related to \"cob\" nor \"cobweb\".\u00a0Old English\u00a0attercoppe\u00a0(meaning \"spider\") is derived from\u00a0atter\u00a0meaning \"poison\" and\u00a0coppe\u00a0meaning \"head\"; Tolkien used \"attercop\" as well as \"cob\" and \"lob\" in\u00a0The Hobbit, where Bilbo Baggins sings songs taunting the giant spiders in Mirkwood: \"Attercop, Attercop, Old Tomnoddy\" and \"Lazy Lob and Crazy Cob\".[citation needed]

", "id": "fcd77445-a93b-4adf-9097-1ad064d91216"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Sauron,\u00a0pronounced\u00a0[\u02c8sa\u028ar\u0254n],[1]\u00a0is the\u00a0title character[note 1]\u00a0and main antagonist of\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. In the same work, he is identified as the\u00a0Necromancer, mentioned in Tolkien's earlier novel\u00a0The Hobbit. In Tolkien's\u00a0The Silmarillion\u00a0(published posthumously by Tolkien's son\u00a0Christopher Tolkien),[3]\u00a0he is also described as the chief lieutenant of the first\u00a0Dark Lord,\u00a0Morgoth. Tolkien noted that the\u00a0\"angelic\" powers of his constructed myth\u00a0\"were capable of many degrees of error and failing\", but by far the worst was \"the absolute\u00a0Satanic\u00a0rebellion and evil of Morgoth and his satellite Sauron\".[4]

", "id": "15df5394-2b97-4c73-bbd9-c7e24105f324"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "Biography", "size": "h2"}, "id": "a01298be-ca6b-41dc-8fb4-841befdb6259"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "Before creation of the world", "size": "h3"}, "id": "a8a32574-dc85-48e7-a5e0-31f1ac2e928b"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The\u00a0Ainulindal\u00eb, the\u00a0cosmological myth\u00a0prefixed to\u00a0The Silmarillion, explains how the supreme being\u00a0Eru\u00a0initiated his creation by bringing into being innumerable spirits, \"the offspring of his thought\", who were with him before anything else had been made. The being later known as Sauron originated as an \"immortal (angelic) spirit\".[5]\u00a0In his origin, Sauron therefore perceived the Creator directly. As Tolkien noted: \"Sauron could not, of course, be a 'sincere'\u00a0atheist. Though one of the minor spirits created before the world, he knew Eru, according to his measure.\"[6]

", "id": "c8a50400-feb7-407c-96cc-8881eecc44fe"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In the terminology of Tolkien's\u00a0invented language\u00a0of\u00a0Quenya, these angelic spirits were called\u00a0Ainur. Those who entered the physical world were called\u00a0Valar, especially the most powerful ones. The (mostly) lesser beings who entered the world, of whom Sauron was one, were called\u00a0Maiar. In Tolkien's letters, the author noted that Sauron \"was of course a 'divine' person (in the terms of this mythology; a lesser member of the race of Valar)\".[7]\u00a0Tolkien noted that he was of a \"far higher order\" than the Maiar who later came to Middle-earth as the\u00a0Wizards\u00a0Gandalf\u00a0and\u00a0Saruman.[8]\u00a0As created by Eru, the Ainur were all good and uncorrupt, as\u00a0Elrond\u00a0stated in\u00a0The Lord of the Rings: \"Nothing is evil in the beginning. Even Sauron was not so.\"[9]

", "id": "f3c02278-f5c5-443e-b952-ef8c1b6a9543"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Rebellion originated with the Vala\u00a0Melkor. According to a story meant as a parable of events beyond\u00a0Elvish\u00a0comprehension,[10]\u00a0Eru let his spirit-children perform a great Music, the\u00a0Music of the Ainur, developing a theme revealed by Eru himself. For a while the cosmic choir made wondrous music, but then Melkor tried to increase his own glory by weaving into his song thoughts and ideas that were not in accordance with the original theme. \"Straightway discord arose around him, and many that sang nigh him grew despondent ... but some began to attune their music to his rather than to the thought which they had at first.\"[11]

", "id": "61d8416b-d6e3-489f-94ae-ee65ac748a68"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The discord Melkor created would have dire consequences, as this singing was a kind of template for the world: \"The evils of the world were not at first in the great Theme, but entered with the discords of Melkor.\"[12]\u00a0However, \"Sauron was not a beginner of discord; and he probably knew more of the Music than did Melkor, whose mind had always been filled with his own plans and devices.\"[13]\u00a0Apparently Sauron was not even one of the spirits that immediately began to attune their music to that of Melkor, since it is noted elsewhere that his fall occurred later (see below).

", "id": "ead94a8b-070d-4101-b76e-37bc5d062315"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The cosmic Music now represented the conflict between\u00a0good and evil. Finally, Eru abruptly brought the Song of Creation to an end. To show the spirits, faithful or otherwise, what they had done, Eru gave independent being to the now-marred Music. This resulted in the manifestation of the material World,\u00a0E\u00e4, where the drama of good and evil would play out and be resolved.

", "id": "107d7773-b7b4-4976-8bca-aff82fbd48ea"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "First Age", "size": "h3"}, "id": "497ea16f-0557-48dc-9ec1-be72fd7c1b15"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In the terminology of Tolkien's\u00a0invented language\u00a0of\u00a0Quenya, these angelic spirits were called\u00a0Ainur. Those who entered the physical world were called\u00a0Valar, especially the most powerful ones. The (mostly) lesser beings who entered the world, of whom Sauron was one, were called\u00a0Maiar. In Tolkien's letters, the author noted that Sauron \"was of course a 'divine' person (in the terms of this mythology; a lesser member of the race of Valar)\".[7]\u00a0Tolkien noted that he was of a \"far higher order\" than the Maiar who later came to Middle-earth as the\u00a0Wizards\u00a0Gandalf\u00a0and\u00a0Saruman.[8]\u00a0As created by Eru, the Ainur were all good and uncorrupt, as\u00a0Elrond\u00a0stated in\u00a0The Lord of the Rings: \"Nothing is evil in the beginning. Even Sauron was not so.\"[9]

", "id": "cbf7b2e8-20e1-4129-aa0c-899f595c1310"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "Sauron's fall", "size": "h4"}, "id": "22adcbaa-6e56-4acd-97f0-448d9911a387"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Melkor opposed the other Valar, who remained faithful to Eru and tried to carry out the Creator's designs. Within the larger universe, they eventually focused on developing the world of\u00a0Arda\u00a0(Earth, or the entire solar system). Around this time, Sauron fell victim to Melkor's corrupting influence: \"In the beginning of Arda, Melkor seduced him to his allegiance.\"[17]

", "id": "27f1ab86-154a-493e-8fbc-756dc3dc8999"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As for Sauron's motives, Tolkien noted that \"it had been his virtue (and therefore also the cause of his fall ...) that he loved order and coordination, and disliked all confusion and wasteful friction\". Thus \"it was the apparent will and power of Melkor to effect his designs quickly and masterfully that had first attracted Sauron to him\".[18]

", "id": "e5063c3e-7dca-4d06-b2ec-a982079328e0"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For a while, Sauron apparently kept up the pretence that he was a faithful servant of the Valar, all the while feeding Melkor information about their doings. Thus, when the Valar made\u00a0Almaren\u00a0as their first physical abode in the world, \"Melkor knew of all that was done; for even then he had secret friends and spies among the Maiar whom he had converted to his cause, and of these the chief, as after became known, was Sauron.\"[14]

", "id": "dc5b3778-e4e1-409b-b8f0-09272b96addc"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Melkor soon destroyed Almaren, and the Valar established a new abode in the Uttermost West: the Blessed Realm of\u00a0Valinor. They still did not perceive Sauron's treachery, for he too became \"a being of Valinor\".[19]

", "id": "db2988a8-bfa6-41ec-9142-904d52700a89"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

At some point, Sauron left the Blessed Realm and went to\u00a0Middle-earth, the central continent of Arda, where Melkor had established his stronghold. In one text, Tolkien wrote of Sauron that \"in Valinor he had dwelt among the hosts of the gods, but there Morgoth had drawn him to evil and to his service\".[20]\u00a0Sauron deserted his service to the Valar and openly joined their great enemy: \"Because of his admiration of Strength he had become a follower of Morgoth and fell with him down into the depths of evil.\"[8]

", "id": "f46bc48e-3b13-4a01-9a4c-c67dcb30ee7a"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "The Lieutenant of Melkor", "size": "h4"}, "id": "80980393-f1c2-461b-bc89-ad288425fc3d"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After joining his new master in Middle-earth, Sauron proved to be a devoted and capable servant: \"While Morgoth still stood, Sauron did not seek his own supremacy, but worked and schemed for another, desiring the triumph of Melkor, whom in the beginning he had adored. He thus was often able to achieve things, first conceived by Melkor, which his master did not or could not complete in the furious haste of his malice.\"[21]\u00a0\"In all the deeds of Melkor the Morgoth upon Arda, in his vast works and in the deceits of his cunning, Sauron had a part.\"[22]

", "id": "75a1c9b4-1b5a-424c-8ddd-d836d18ce946"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In chapter three of\u00a0The Silmarillion, Tolkien writes that by the time the\u00a0Elves\u00a0awoke in the world, Sauron had become Melkor's lieutenant and was given command over the newly built stronghold of\u00a0Angband. To protect the Elves, the Valar made war on Melkor and captured him, but could not find Sauron.

", "id": "d8ccc54c-1828-472f-a090-dbcec7be59b2"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Thus, \"when Melkor was made captive, Sauron escaped and lay hid in Middle-earth; and it can in this way be understood how the breeding of the\u00a0Orcs\u00a0(no doubt already begun) went on with increasing speed\". In the Blessed Realm, Melkor feigned reform, but eventually escaped back to Middle-earth, holding the\u00a0Silmarils\u00a0of\u00a0F\u00ebanor. By then, Sauron had \"secretly repaired Angband for the help of his Master when he returned; and there the dark places underground were already manned with hosts of the Orcs before Melkor came back at last, as Morgoth the Black Enemy\".[23]

", "id": "d356b8b9-ab2b-4cad-ad73-3fb3cd26006f"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Shortly after the return of Morgoth, the\u00a0Noldorin\u00a0Elves also left the\u00a0Blessed Realm of Valinor\u00a0in the Uttermost West, against the counsel of the Valar, to wage war on Morgoth, who had stolen the Silmarils. In that war, Sauron served as Morgoth's chief lieutenant, surpassing all others in rank, such as\u00a0Gothmog, the Lord of\u00a0Balrogs. Known as\u00a0Gorthaur the Cruel, Sauron was at that time a master of illusions and\u00a0shapeshifting;\u00a0werewolves\u00a0and vampires were his servants, chief among them\u00a0Draugluin, Father of Werewolves, and his vampire herald\u00a0Thuringwethil.

", "id": "ac11e5a9-b64a-49bd-840e-c2dcafdab6fa"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When Morgoth left Angband to corrupt the newly discovered\u00a0Men, Sauron directed the war against the Elves. He conquered the Elvish island of Tol Sirion and its watchtower\u00a0Minas Tirith, so that it became known as\u00a0Tol-in-Gaurhoth,\u00a0the Isle of Werewolves.

", "id": "02055004-aaa2-440f-880c-6758679b102a"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I am May, I was raised in the Mekong Delta. I first worked as a social worker and then after university he became an English teacher. After growing up, working throughout the Mekong Delta, I decided to become a tour guide. Since 2009, I has been a freelance biking tour guide all over Myanmar for different tour companies. I understands the country, people and their customs. This allows me to take visitors into the countryside to meet local people and experience the real rural life.

As a child of the countryside I can easily help guests get closer with local people, their culture and way of life,...through biking. Everyone falls in love with the places that I leads them to.

", "id": "3fa83f0f-5445-4d99-a8df-bc770f84d904"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

My name is Than, i am a tour guide in Yangon city Myanmar. i would like to introduce to all of people on the world about our country. So please contact me for your enjoyable trip to Myanmar.


Thank you for your attention !

", "id": "f5b738c5-55e2-457d-b582-ffb7bff8af10"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Travel Writer, Photographer, Earth Advocate and Beauty Seeker.\u00a0
More about me on my blog - (URL HIDDEN)

", "id": "1dfc0527-db64-4ff8-b315-f0e31922b976"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Gandalf\u00a0/\u02c8\u0261\u00e6nd\u0251\u02d0lf/[2]\u00a0is a\u00a0fictional character\u00a0and one of the protagonists in\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's novels\u00a0The Hobbit\u00a0and\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. He is a\u00a0wizard, member of the\u00a0Istari\u00a0order, as well as leader of the\u00a0Fellowship of the Ring\u00a0and the army of the West. In\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, he is initially known as\u00a0Gandalf the Grey, but returns from death as\u00a0Gandalf the White.

", "id": "5c2ba644-7c35-48fa-a759-7abcba92727b"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "The Fellowship of the Ring", "size": "h2"}, "id": "aa7ee466-c581-4817-bd9a-3869b6262afb"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Returning to\u00a0the Shire, in\u00a0T.A.\u00a03018, Gandalf confirmed his suspicions by throwing\u00a0the Ring\u00a0into\u00a0Frodo's hearth-fire and reading the writing that appeared on\u00a0the Ring's surface. He told Frodo the full history of the Ring, and urged him to take the Ring to\u00a0Rivendell; for he would be in grave danger if he stayed in the Shire. Gandalf said he would attempt to return for Frodo's 50th birthday party, in order to accompany him on the road thereafter; and that meanwhile Frodo should arrange to leave quietly, as the servants of\u00a0Sauron\u00a0would be searching for him.

", "id": "d5a381b1-ba5f-4b18-bce6-3cce29d8000a"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Outside the Shire, Gandalf encountered\u00a0Radagast the Brown, another of the Istari, who brought the news that the\u00a0Nazg\u00fbl\u00a0had ridden forth and crossed the River\u00a0Anduin\u2014and a request from\u00a0Saruman\u00a0that Gandalf come to\u00a0Isengard. Gandalf left a\u00a0letter\u00a0to Frodo (urging his immediate departure) with\u00a0Barliman Butterbur\u00a0at the inn in\u00a0Bree, and headed towards Isengard. There Saruman revealed his true colours, urging Gandalf to help him obtain the Ring for his own use. Gandalf refused, and Saruman imprisoned him at the top of the tower of\u00a0Orthanc. Eventually Gandalf was rescued by\u00a0Gwaihir\u00a0the\u00a0Eagle.

", "id": "c4188090-6b47-4fab-8492-812c5620467e"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Gwaihir set Gandalf down in\u00a0Rohan, where Gandalf appealed to King\u00a0Th\u00e9oden\u00a0for a horse. Th\u00e9oden, under the malign influence of\u00a0Gr\u00edma Wormtongue, Saruman's spy, told Gandalf to take any horse he pleased, but to leave quickly. It was then that Gandalf met the great horse\u00a0Shadowfax, one of the\u00a0mearas, who would be his mount and companion for most of the rest of the war. Gandalf pursued the horse for two days[6]\u00a0before Shadowfax permitted Gandalf to ride him. Gandalf then rode hard for the Shire, but did not reach it until Frodo had already set out. Knowing that Frodo and his companions would be heading for Rivendell, Gandalf began to make his own way there. He learned at Bree that the Hobbits had fallen in with\u00a0Aragorn. He faced the Nazg\u00fbl at\u00a0Weathertop\u00a0but escaped after an all-night battle, drawing four of them northward. Frodo, Aragorn and company faced the remaining five on Weathertop a few nights later. Gandalf reached Rivendell just before Frodo's arrival.

", "id": "0cb86ea2-42d7-44d5-87da-26d9d97428f1"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In Rivendell, Gandalf helped\u00a0Elrond\u00a0drive off the Nazg\u00fbl pursuing Frodo and played a great part in the following\u00a0council\u00a0as the only person who knew the full history of the Ring. He also revealed that Saruman had betrayed them and was in league with Sauron. When it was decided that the Ring had to be destroyed, Gandalf volunteered to accompany Frodo\u2014now the Ring-bearer\u2014in his quest. He also persuaded Elrond to let Frodo's cousins\u00a0Merry\u00a0and\u00a0Pippin\u00a0join the\u00a0Fellowship.

", "id": "b6ac268f-e2c4-4f1b-a7fe-7dfb03b626d8"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Taking charge of the Fellowship (comprising nine representatives of the free hostss of\u00a0Middle-earth, \"set against the Nine Riders\"), Gandalf and Aragorn led the Hobbits and their companions south. After an unsuccessful attempt to cross Mount\u00a0Caradhras\u00a0in winter, they crossed\u00a0under\u00a0the mountains through the Mines of\u00a0Moria, though only\u00a0Gimli\u00a0the\u00a0Dwarf\u00a0was enthusiastic about that route. In Moria, they discovered that the Dwarf colony established there earlier had been overrun by\u00a0Orcs. The Fellowship fought with the Orcs and Trolls of Moria and escaped them.

", "id": "a9b8d602-0418-4731-90c2-ba2cead66004"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

At the\u00a0Bridge of Khazad-d\u00fbm, they encountered \"Durin's Bane,\" a fearsome\u00a0Balrog\u00a0from ancient times. Gandalf faced the Balrog to enable the others to escape. After a brief exchange of blows, Gandalf broke the bridge beneath the Balrog with his\u00a0staff. As the Balrog fell, it wrapped its whip around Gandalf's legs, dragging him over the edge. As his friends looked on in horror, Gandalf fell into the abyss, crying \"Fly, you fools!\" as he went.

", "id": "fb85b0bc-14ca-448a-882d-8c446734b67d"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After a long fall, Gandalf and the Balrog crashed into a deep subterranean lake far under Moria. Gandalf pursued the Balrog through the tunnels for eight days until they climbed to the peak of\u00a0Zirakzigil. Here they fought for two days and nights. In the end, the Balrog was defeated and cast down onto the mountainside. Gandalf himself died shortly afterwards, and his body lay on the peak while his spirit travelled \"out of thought and time\".

", "id": "4de69fc2-ffef-4aa8-ad0c-fb9c9fae9d7c"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Bilbo Baggins\u00a0is the\u00a0title character\u00a0and\u00a0protagonist\u00a0of\u00a0J. R. R. Tolkien's 1937 novel\u00a0The Hobbit, as well as a\u00a0supporting character\u00a0in\u00a0The Lord of the Rings. In Tolkien's narrative\u00a0conceit, in which all the writings of\u00a0Middle-earth\u00a0are translations from the fictitious volume of\u00a0The\u00a0Red Book of Westmarch, Bilbo is the author of\u00a0The Hobbit\u00a0and translator of various \"works from the\u00a0elvish\" (as mentioned in the end of\u00a0The Return of the King).

", "id": "25696283-eba6-43c6-8479-08d1b6975a06"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "The Hobbit", "size": "h2"}, "id": "e29b6e8d-6fb9-4620-9e2c-e45cf341dd79"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"image": 28, "caption": "Bilbo Baggins illustration", "style": "half"}, "id": "2d56b90b-02a6-40ce-8ab4-cf02c8adad59"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In\u00a0The Hobbit, Bilbo Baggins, a\u00a0hobbit\u00a0in comfortable middle age at 50 years old, was hired despite his objections as a \"burglar\" by the\u00a0wizard\u00a0Gandalf\u00a0and\u00a013 Dwarves\u00a0led by their king\u00a0Thorin Oakenshield\u00a0on a quest to reclaim the\u00a0Lonely Mountain\u00a0and its treasure from the\u00a0dragon\u00a0Smaug. The adventure took Bilbo and the companions through the wilderness, to the\u00a0elf\u00a0haven of\u00a0Rivendell, across the\u00a0Misty Mountains\u00a0and the black forest of\u00a0Mirkwood, to\u00a0Lake-town\u00a0in the middle of\u00a0Long Lake, and eventually to the Mountain itself. Here, after the dragon was killed and the Mountain was reclaimed, soon after that the\u00a0Battle of Five Armies\u00a0took place.

", "id": "8e5441ca-af0d-4dd5-a284-73b52556ba7f"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In his journey, Bilbo encountered other fantastic creatures, including\u00a0trolls, elves,\u00a0giant spiders, a\u00a0man who can change shape into a bear,\u00a0goblins,\u00a0eagles,\u00a0wolves\u00a0and a slimy, murderous creature named\u00a0Gollum. Underground, near Gollum's lair, Bilbo accidentally found a\u00a0magic ring of invisibility, which he used to escape from Gollum.

", "id": "38f17b45-d5c3-44cf-b1c5-794a9053502d"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

By the end of the journey, Bilbo had become wiser and more confident, having saved the day in many precarious situations. Bilbo's journey has been compared to a pilgrimage of grace. The Hobbit can be characterized as a \"Christian\u00a0bildungsroman\u00a0which equates progress to wisdom gained in the form of a rite of passage.[1]\u00a0He rescued the dwarves from giant spiders with the magic ring and a short\u00a0Elven-sword\u00a0he acquired. He used the ring to sneak around in dangerous places, as well as his wits to smuggle the dwarves out of the elves' prisons. When tensions arose over ownership of the recovered treasure, he tried unsuccessfully to bring the opposing sides to compromise, using the\u00a0Arkenstone, a stolen heirloom jewel, as leverage. This strained his relationship with Thorin, but the two were reconciled at Thorin's deathbed. At the end of the story, Bilbo returned to his home in\u00a0the Shire\u00a0only to find that several of his relatives, believing him to be dead, were trying to claim his home and possessions. In addition to becoming wealthy from his share of the dwarves' treasure, he found that he, like\u00a0Adam, had traded respectability for experience and wisdom. At the end, Gandalf proclaims Bilbo is no longer the Hobbit he was. This is certainly true as Bilbo has fully matured. Continuing the pilgrimage theme, a true pilgrimage does not end at the destination, but rather when the wanderer is absolved, blessed, and ready to return home.[1]

", "id": "11a9802f-651b-431b-9d93-aa11617a5182"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "The Lord of the Rings", "size": "h2"}, "id": "d2b35a44-8cc4-41ab-83d3-bea155904a2d"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Fellowship of the Ring, the first volume of\u00a0The Lord of the Rings, begins with Bilbo's \"eleventy-first\" (111th) birthday, 60 years after the beginning of\u00a0The Hobbit. The main character of the novel is\u00a0Frodo Baggins, Bilbo's cousin,[nb 1]\u00a0who celebrates his 33rd birthday and legally comes of age on the same day.

", "id": "0f7bbcad-af7b-4dbc-8e77-dd49a7c10d88"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In\u00a0T.A.\u00a02989 (S.R.\u00a01389), Bilbo, a lifelong bachelor, adopted Frodo, the orphaned son of his first cousin\u00a0Primula Brandybuck\u00a0and his second cousin\u00a0Drogo Baggins, and made him his heir. Though Frodo was actually \"his first\u00a0and\u00a0second\u00a0cousin once removed\u00a0either way\",[2]\u00a0the two regarded each other as uncle and nephew.

", "id": "f5624f25-5c76-40d0-96e0-476619476af5"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

All this time Bilbo had kept his magic ring, with no idea of its significance, using it mostly to hide from his obnoxious cousins, the\u00a0Sackville-Bagginses, when they came to visit.\u00a0Gandalf's investigations revealed it to be the\u00a0One Ring\u00a0forged by the Dark Lord\u00a0Sauron. The Ring had prolonged Bilbo's life beyond the normal hobbit span, and at 111 he still looked 50. While the Ring did not initially corrupt him as it had its previous owners, it was beginning to affect him; over the years, it had begun to prey on his mind when out of his sight, and he lost sleep and felt \"thin, sort of\u00a0stretched\u00a0\u2026 like butter that has been scraped over too much bread\".[2]

", "id": "cc9b468c-91bf-4237-96e3-77a33b9a6a89"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

On the night of his and Frodo's birthday, Bilbo threw himself a party and invited all of the Shire. He signed his home,\u00a0Bag End, and estate over to Frodo. He then gave a farewell address to his neighbors, at the end of which he put on the Ring and vanished from sight. As Bilbo prepared finally to leave the house, he reacted with panic and suspicion when Gandalf tried to persuade him to leave the Ring with Frodo. Bilbo refused to give up the Ring, referring to it as his \"precious\" \u2013 just as Gollum had. Gandalf lost his temper with his old friend and talked some sense into him. Bilbo admitted he would have liked to be rid of the Ring, and he left it behind, becoming the first person to do so voluntarily. He left the Shire that night, and was never seen in\u00a0Hobbiton\u00a0again.

", "id": "88716897-be37-49e7-ad80-c402446407f1"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

His earlier adventure, his\u00a0eccentric\u00a0habits as a hobbit, and his sudden disappearance led to the enduring figure of \"Mad Baggins\" in hobbit folklore, who disappeared with a flash and a bang and returned with gold and jewels.

", "id": "1dfaa47a-1dca-4ca5-b22f-197de49ec23b"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Freed of the Ring's power over his senses, Bilbo travelled first to\u00a0Rivendell, and then on to visit the dwarves of the Lonely Mountain. After he returned to Rivendell he spent much of the next 17 years living a pleasant life of retirement: eating, sleeping, writing poetry, and working on his memoirs,\u00a0There and Back Again, known as\u00a0The Hobbit. He became a scholar of Elven lore, leaving behind the\u00a0Translations from the\u00a0Elvish, which forms the basis of what is known to us as\u00a0The Silmarillion.

", "id": "e322cf82-4d99-46f1-8497-a7066712329a"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When Frodo and his friends\u00a0Samwise Gamgee,\u00a0Meriadoc Brandybuck\u00a0and\u00a0Peregrin Took\u00a0stopped in Rivendell on their quest to destroy the Ring, Bilbo was still alive but now visibly aged, the years having caught up with him after he surrendered the Ring. Upon seeing the Ring again, he suddenly tried to take it from Frodo; he returned to his senses when a terrified Frodo backed away, and he broke down in tears, apologizing for bringing the burden of the Ring onto Frodo.

", "id": "a1ccee2c-6c2c-4f86-bd9a-aa1531ee407c"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After the quest to destroy the Ring was fulfilled in\u00a0The Return of the King, Gandalf and the four Hobbits visited Rivendell on their way back to the Shire and found Bilbo still living there. He gave Frodo a set of manuscripts that later became\u00a0Translations from the Elvish, and also gave Sam a small bag of gold that represented the last of his share from Smaug's vast hoard. Two years later Bilbo accompanied Gandalf,\u00a0Elrond,\u00a0Galadriel, and Frodo to the\u00a0Grey Havens, there to take ship for\u00a0Tol Eress\u00eba\u00a0across the sea, on 29th 'September'\u00a0T.A.\u00a03021. He had already celebrated his 131st birthday by this time, surpassing the\u00a0Old Took\u00a0by one year and becoming the oldest Hobbit ever in Middle-earth. (The natural lifespan of Hobbits is about 100 years.)[3]

", "id": "2f4c927c-0cfc-49a0-a455-a5ad18c749e8"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Hi there, my name is Wynee. I have been working as a tour guide for over a decade, I have lots of experience taking tourists to some of the amazing places in Myanmar. I hold Psychology degree from Yangon University and I love vegeterian food.

", "id": "261a3a95-68c8-4aaf-9183-dabe28295044"}]

fields.introduction: We provide amazing experiences in some of the best places in Myanmar.

fields.body:
[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Mandalay is the second largest city in Burma (after Yangon), and a former capital of Myanmar. The city is the economic and religious hub of upper Myanmar and is centred around the Royal Palace.

", "id": "e41b11fa-1fdf-45f4-a44d-0257c31b8bcb"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"image": 73, "caption": "Palace of Mandalay", "style": "half"}, "id": "40e190fd-2fee-4079-90b6-7f3ede2e15aa"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It has wide lanes filled with bicycles and motorcycles and is known for its cultural diversity. Half of Burma's monks reside in Mandalay and the surrounding areas.

", "id": "303bda1e-46f7-45c2-98ed-3b1554633efd"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Mandalay, the very name evokes the splendours of the Burma of old. But, most people will be surprised to learn that Mandalay is not an old city, not even a medieval one, but rather a new city that was created by King Mingdon Min of Burma in 1857 as the new capital of the kingdom of Ava. Only two Burmese kings ruled from there, King Mingdon and King Thibaw, before the British conquest of Upper Burma in 1885. It was a city of splendour between 1858 and 1885 but most of the magnificence is gone, destroyed by the fire that consumed wooden structures and by intensive bombing by the Axis powers during the Second World War. The city, neatly planned with its lettered roads and numbered streets, is a British creation. The once magnificent Royal Palace and the great Atumashi (incomparable) pagoda, King Mingdon Min's finest creations, are modern reconstructions. Today, Mandalay lies at the end of the Lashio Road and it is, by Burmese standards, relatively prosperous as a centre for trade with China and as a centre for the growing trade with India. Despite the capital having been moved to Naypyidaw, Mandalay remains by far the main commercial centre of Upper Myanmar.

", "id": "401dbb4b-c525-4a64-92dd-41c51088568b"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Inle Lake is a shallow lake in the middle of Myanmar, south-east of Mandalay. The lake is 22km long, and is densely inhabited by many different tribes.

", "id": "f131f4de-bbba-4fd9-8e1a-b23fe7fa0a13"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"image": 69, "caption": "Inle Paungdaw Oo Pagoda", "style": "half"}, "id": "7dab4deb-f1b0-420b-b394-989752267bb9"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The easiest way to get into Inle Lake (and the most comfortable) is by domestic flight. The closest airport is in Heho, which is a taxi-ride (about 1 hour) away from the lake itself (walking down the road from the airport, towards the highway, should see quoted fares drop, if not, try your luck hailing a taxi or passing pickup on the highway itself). Taking a taxi from the airport is expensive, as of January 2017 there is a fixed, non-bargainable price of 25,000 Kyats to go to Nyuang Shwe. If you baulk at the high fare, the taxi drivers will attempt to gather other travelers to share the taxi and split the fare, so there is a good chance you will end up paying a lot less by sharing your taxi. By comparison a taxi from Yangon airport to the city centre (45 min.) is just 8000 Kyats or 7 USD. A possible way to save money is to book a taxi in advance with your guesthouse, but seems like now they all charge the same 25,000 kyat fixed price. 15,000kyat is a good price to/from the airport that may be more difficult to reserve on your way in, but no issue to book for your return trip to Heho from any agency in town. When returning, you can often save by booking a shared taxi through your hotel or one of the many travel agents around. Check with them the day before you fly out.

", "id": "3d2d6737-c19b-403e-96de-88ef0a42c638"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Prices for flights are around US$110 from Yangon and US$75 from Mandalay, but unlike bus companies the government is heavily involved in the domestic air market, a good chunk of your money will be going into their hands.

", "id": "62280a41-1acc-463e-9407-cd9aa2040c75"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Bagan, located on the banks of the Ayeyarwady (Irrawaddy) River, is home to the largest and densest concentration of Buddhist temples, pagodas, stupas and ruins in the world with many dating from the 11th and 12th centuries. The shape and construction of each building is highly significant in Buddhism with each component part taking on spiritual meaning.

", "id": "1b70eea3-3d2c-4efb-a0f2-d5f65135dba9"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "


With regards to tour comparison between this immense archeological site and the other significant archeological gem of Southeast Asia, the Angkor sites, this analogy may be helpful:

", "id": "a5e2e5a9-afb3-423c-b559-87a5fa7427bc"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "


Angkor ruins are like a Chinese Lauriat banquet where food is presented in spectacular servings with a suspenseful wait between items which are hidden beneath curtains of forests. On the other hand, Bagan is served in Spanish Tapas style, the ingredients exposed to the customer and shown in small bite-size servings, with the next attraction close and visible at hand, in shorter intervals.

", "id": "e2bf0206-0058-4ed3-bc9f-2e89948e5c62"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"image": 70, "caption": "Sunset in Bagan", "style": "full"}, "id": "5ecb9986-28bc-40e3-b268-94c4ef55d0ad"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "


Another analogy between Angkor and Bagan Sites when distinguishing temple structures is through their stupa and spire shapes.

", "id": "263c3dde-bd75-43b5-b911-d4d122b721aa"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "


Artichokes and corncobs = Angkor while gourds and durians (or pineapple) = Bagan.

", "id": "6878da8f-2eeb-44fe-be30-0c2e6489066c"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "


An example is gourd for Shwezigon Pagoda and durian for Ananda, Thatbyinnyu, and Mahabodi Temples. In another way of imagining, Bagan temples are like topped with inverted ice cream cones.

", "id": "bd79b570-7680-45aa-a2af-57a58418ee98"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "


What makes the temples look romantic is the process of graceful aging. For some reason, there are no windbreakers around as shown by the barren, desert-dry mountain range to the west past the river, spinning occasional micro twisters that spawn loose dust particles everywhere from the eroded earth to the structures. This phenomenon had peeled off so much the stucco coating of the temples to reveal the brick structural blocks with its rusty, reddish, and sometimes golden brown-like patina when hit by the sun's rays.

", "id": "23d1b228-c6ff-4ba5-a9ac-c1d5bdc7765c"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Erosion is a significant threat to this area, not only the wind chipping away the buildings' plastering but also water from the mighty Ayeyarwady (Irrawaddy) River threatens the riverbanks. The strong river current has already washed away half of the area of Old Bagan. It used to be a rectangular-shaped piece of enclave protected by a perimeter wall. Now what remains is roughly the triangular eastern half part.

", "id": "237eefec-f8bb-41da-9b46-1337df84583a"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Other images of Bagan which make a lasting impression to tourists aside from the spire-fringed skyline; stupas sporting that tumbledown look yet crowned with glitter-studded golden miter-like sikaras; the ubiquitous pair of ferocious stone lions flanking a temple's door; the spiky and lacy eave fascia woodcarvings lining a monastery's ascending tiers of roofs; tall palmyras or toddy palms with willowy trunks, bougainvilleas, exotic cotton trees, and the likes bringing life to the arid landscape and abandoned ruins; squirrels playfully and acrobatically scampering on the walls and pediments of temples; horse drawn carriages lazily carrying drop-jawed tourists; sleepy moving grandfather's bullock carts grinding on a dust-choked trail; not to mention the garbage left around, stray dogs loitering, longyi clad men spitting betel chews in copious amounts everywhere, overgrown weeds and the pestering dust.

", "id": "e2e14d8c-81c9-48be-84c8-11c62f967879"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Taunggyi is best known for the annual Fire Balloon festival held for one week near the beginning of November each year. For most of every day, hot air paper balloons several metres in length in the shape of various animals are launched and sent floating over the town (if they don't spontaneously combust on take-off, a relatively common occurrence). In the evening the carnival really gets going with the launching of more traditionally shaped balloons carrying cargoes of sweets and fireworks. Definitely one of Myanmar's must-see events, but be warned that hotel prices increase by about 50% during the festival. It's popular with locals, but hardly any foreigners attend.


", "id": "4a59ef3d-f011-444a-8c06-7e783e8837e6"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"image": 72, "caption": "Balloon festival in Taungyi", "style": "half"}, "id": "491133c5-4c4e-47b6-8034-cf4d5eaa310b"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The market in Taunggyi is worth seeing. Shan noodles and Burmese sweet tea can be purchased at low costs, and CDs and VCDs are cheap and abundant. Another attraction of the market is the abundance of Pa-O (distinguished by interesting headscarves) women selling fresh produce and inexpensive tea from the Shan hills.

", "id": "52bddaa5-acd0-43eb-981e-8469bef1cc51"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You can take a bus from Pathein or Yangon. The roads are better now , so for the about 260km from Yangon it will take about 5 hours, depending what bus you take. There are morning buses (i.e. 6:30am and 7:30am depending on demand, 10000 kyat) that depart from the western Yangon bus terminal (Hlaing Thar Yar Bus Terminal) which is 45 minutes by car taxi from the city centre. There is a bus service (4000 kyat) departing Pathein for Ngwe Saung at 2:00pm again depending on demand, if you miss that hire a moto taxi or jump in a jumbo for 5000 kyat or less (bargain hard!).

", "id": "1879d98d-98a0-4f7e-ac50-73b87dcc7571"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Hiring a car is only worth it if you have missed the morning bus and do not want to ride by night. The difference in time is not big. It will cost around 120$.


", "id": "6f6d3002-9e57-4ca5-85b8-6d55c794a73e"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"image": 71, "caption": "Beautiful beach in Ngwe Saung", "style": "half"}, "id": "b12e6c7b-8377-4d42-a0e3-7da16439a0d2"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you're travelling from Pathein, you can also catch a minivan. It departs from the bus station near Shwezigon Pagoda, the same bus station the local bus leaves from. It's a dark green Toyota Minivan with 'Beach Express' written in red writing on the front and sides. It leaves at 9am and 1pm and charges 3600 Kyat.

", "id": "3180e2cc-5f35-434d-b9ee-d941a0d4b9fb"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "


There is no longer a requirement to remit a copy of your visa and passport prior at a military check point on the way to Ngwe Saung.

", "id": "2a5c8c5f-bf41-4c8d-a773-7b370d807487"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Passports were handed to the bus operator who did have to show them to guards on the way to Ngwe Saung.

", "id": "1dbfb800-5f95-4cc1-928d-458389e4a035"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Mawlamyine (Moulmein/Moulmien) is the capital of Mon State in Southeastern Myanmar. Mawlamyine is the fourth largest city in Myanmar with a population of 326,000. It was captured by the British in 1826 during the First Anglo-Burmese War and served as their capital from 1827 to 1852. Even though the population is quite large the city itself looks and feels like only a small town, making it pleasant to walk around. Mawlamyine is pronounced \"more-la-mine\".

", "id": "161554a7-5102-401b-bf79-f9ce64265d0d"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Yangon, formerly Rangoon, was the capital of Myanmar until it was superseded by Naypyidaw in November 2005. Today, with a population of over 5 million people, it remains the largest city and main economic hub of Myanmar.

", "id": "cb8515ea-5620-4353-8857-5d5a3ed61050"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-DuMKYv8M5Q", "id": "843ac96a-8b61-4539-aeef-480b803bc838"}, {"type": "header", "value": {"header_text": "Geography", "size": "h2"}, "id": "eeed4cd4-4b2a-4288-8943-8c368ce22443"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "


The city is an amalgamation of British, Burmese, Chinese and Indian influences, and is known for its colonial architecture, which although decaying and beyond appreciation, remains an almost unique example of a 19th-century British colonial capital. New high-rise buildings were constructed from the 1990s (and some are scarily unoccupied and left as ghost skyscrapers and hotels as seen along Upper Pansodan Rd) as the government began to allow private investment (while former national government buildings such as the massive Secretariat Building, as the capital is shifted to Naypyidaw, have been left to rot). However, Yangon continues to be a city of the past, as seen by its longyi-wearing, betel nut chewing and spitting pedestrians, their friendly or even familial attitude towards strangers, its street vendors and its pungent smells.


", "id": "00b7d5cb-6b42-4a37-b368-1cf363318dc3"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "


Yangon's former name is not the only victim of symbolic changes in this country. For one, the country's name has been changed. To add up to this identity crisis going on in this country, this city has been stripped of its capital status, the capital relocated to a secluded new site called Naypyidaw built from scratch. The flag too has been changed, recently redesigned in 2010, replacing the old one which replaced another one slightly more than a decade earlier.


", "id": "6de0c7a1-47f9-4eaf-af4a-74ab9d7b8f26"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"image": 74, "caption": "Yangon colonial building", "style": "half"}, "id": "98542ef9-ee34-4383-aece-3b692dcce59e"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

One noticeable observation is seen along Yangon's southern streets perpendicular to the river. Diagonal parking is set off against the traffic direction in these one-way streets.

", "id": "4cda934f-1e60-463f-bf1a-47369b6bc15c"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Naypyidaw is a unique city in the region. It is a fully constructed large city but with very few inhabitants compared to its size, so you can experience the amazing and unprecedented (for Asia) experience of never ever being stuck in traffic. It is between two mountain ranges so has little to offer in the way of day trips or activities. The city was constructed to be the capital by the military and lacks the dissarray and wonder found throughout the rest of Myanmar.

", "id": "aac9a0ec-30f6-42e6-8b3b-5567811fb085"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Naypyidaw was constructed in secret by the Myanmar Junta in the early 2000s. In November 2005 it was officially announced as the country's new capital. Government workers were given two months notice that they would have to move from Yangon, as all government offices and ministries were relocated. Embassies and international organisations like the UN have not yet relocated but are expected to at some point. The international retail chains found throughout all other capital cities are not present in Naypyidaw.

", "id": "34bc4d82-049d-4e93-bdc2-fa5e9627bd67"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The city has wide boulevards/highways (still almost empty) and extravagant roundabouts. It has housing for government workers, but many still maintain residences for their families in Yangon as education and health infrastructure is not yet in place.

", "id": "096b1ed1-e9a1-406d-b7c3-322bbad94bf6"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"image": 68, "caption": "Pagoda in Naypyidaw", "style": "half"}, "id": "030fecde-4c86-4be3-b249-9251e5912c21"}]

fields.strapline: The Road goes ever on and on, out from the door where it began.
fields.copyright_notice: Disclaimer: This is only a demo site for Doolay. The the experiences and tour guides you see here are stub only. They are not real.
